Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2017 02:17PM - edited Mar 9, 2017 02:26PM by Shelly52 Hi Daniell, I think it's a bit different for everyone but I suggest that you will know when its time. For me there was really no choice. It began coming out in clumps. I didn't shave mine until the very end - - because i dreaded it so much. But - - when the obvious time came it was during a shower. I finished my shower, went over to the sink and just started cutting. I have a shaver that I used on my son. As much as I dreaded it, by that time I felt a little relieved to get it over with. I wore cotton hats or my wig from then on. I really did get used to it and even liked how quickly I could get ready in the morning. I really hate that you are having to go through this. It really stinks. No doubt about it. Daniell- you WILL get through it and be amazed how strong you really are. Good thing is that taxol is pretty tolerable. It was for me. Wishing you all the best. Hugs to you. ~ Shelly

Posts.Content: May 20, 2016 01:39AM Shelly52 wrote: imjakes - I finished chemo Dec 18 so we have a similar timeframe. I got taxol instead of taxotere. I am getting hair growth but I am experiencing a new loss of eyelashes and brows, too. I read somewhere that this is normal because the lashes all came in at the same time and are on the same "schedule" so to speak. They have a natural shed period and many will drop on the same timeframe. After a while the dropped lashes will spread out so that we won't notice when we lose one or two at a time. This makes sense to me also I can see the new ones coming in again. I wish I had magic words for your hair. It sounds like you are doing all the right things. The only thing you didn't mention that I do is to run a soft brush or gentle comb over your scalp periodically. When i do it, it makes my scalp tingle bit. I think it draws blood to the scalp. This may or may not be the case but why not, huh? PS. You aredarling with or without hair.
